19.verse: Eventually the master came back from his travels, found his slaves, and settled up with them.

20.verse: The slave who had been given five talents came forward and told his master how he’d turned five into ten; then he handed the whole lot over to his master.

21.verse: Master: Excellent. You’ve proved yourself not only clever but loyal. You’ve executed a rather small task masterfully, so now I am going to put you in charge of something larger. But before you go back to work, come join my great feast and celebration.

22.verse: Then the slave who had been given two talents came forward and told his master how he’d turned two into four, and he handed all four talents to his master.

23.verse: Master: Excellent. You’ve proved yourself not only clever but loyal. You’ve executed a rather small task masterfully, so now I am going to put you in charge of something larger. But before you go back to work, come join my great feast and celebration.

24.verse: Finally the man who had been given one talent came forward. Servant: Master, I know you are a hard man, difficult in every way. You can make a healthy sum when others would fail. You profit when other people are doing the work. You grow rich on the backs of others.

25.verse: So I was afraid, dug a hole, and hid the talent in the ground. Here it is. You can have it.

26.verse: The master was furious. Master: You are a pathetic excuse for a servant! You have disproved my trust in you and squandered my generosity. You know I always make a profit!

27.verse: You could have at least put this talent in the bank; then I could have earned a little interest on it!

28.verse: Take that one talent away, and give it to the servant who doubled my money from five to ten.

29.verse: You see, everything was taken away from the man who had nothing, but the man who had something got even more.

30.verse: And as for the slave who made no profit but buried his talent in the ground? His master ordered his slaves to tie him up and throw him outside into the utter darkness where there is miserable mourning and great fear.

31.verse: When the Son of Man comes in all His majesty accompanied by throngs of heavenly messengers, His throne will be wondrous.

32.verse: All the nations will assemble before Him, and He will judge them, distinguishing them from one another as a shepherd isolates the sheep from the goats.

33.verse: He will put some, the sheep, at His right hand and some, the goats, at His left.

34.verse: Then the King will say to those to His right, King: Come here, you beloved, you people whom My Father has blessed. Claim your inheritance, the Kingdom prepared for you from the beginning of creation.

35.verse: You shall be richly rewarded, for when I was hungry, you fed Me. And when I was thirsty, you gave Me something to drink. I was alone as a stranger, and you welcomed Me into your homes and into your lives.

36.verse: I was naked, and you gave Me clothes to wear; I was sick, and you tended to My needs; I was in prison, and you comforted Me.

37.verse: Even then the righteous will not have achieved perfect understanding and will not recall these things. Righteous: Master, when did we find You hungry and give You food? When did we find You thirsty and slake Your thirst?

38.verse: When did we find You a stranger and welcome You in, or find You naked and clothe You?

39.verse: When did we find You sick and nurse You to health? When did we visit You when You were in prison?

40.verse: King: I tell you this: whenever you saw a brother or sister hungry or cold, whatever you did to the least of these, so you did to Me.

41.verse: At that He will turn to those on His left hand. King: Get away from Me, you despised people whom My Father has cursed. Claim your inheritance—the pits of flaming hell where the devil and his minions suffer.

42.verse: For I was starving, and you left Me with no food. When I was dry and thirsty, you left Me to struggle with nothing to drink.

43.verse: When I was alone as a stranger, you turned away from Me. When I was pitifully naked, you left Me unclothed. When I was sick, you gave Me no care. When I was in prison, you did not comfort Me.

44.verse: Unrighteous: Master, when did we see You hungry and thirsty? When did we see You friendless or homeless or excluded? When did we see You without clothes? When did we see You sick or in jail? When did we see You in distress and fail to respond?

45.verse: King: I tell you this: whenever you saw a brother hungry or cold, when you saw a sister weak and without friends, when you saw the least of these and ignored their suffering, so you ignored Me.

46.verse: So these, the goats, will go off to everlasting punishment. But the beloved, the sheep (the righteous), will go into everlasting life.

1.verse: And so this is what happened, finally. Jesus finished all His teaching, and He said to His disciples,

2.verse: Jesus: The feast of Passover begins in two days. That is when the Son of Man is handed over to be crucified.

3.verse: And almost as He spoke, the chief priests were getting together with the elders at the home of the high priest, Caiaphas.

4.verse: They schemed and mused about how they could trick Jesus, sneak around and capture Him, and then kill Him.

5.verse: Chief Priests: We shouldn’t try to catch Him at the great public festival. The people would riot if they knew what we were doing.

6.verse: Meanwhile Jesus was at Bethany staying at the home of Simon the leper.

7.verse: While He was at Simon’s house, a woman came to see Him. She had an alabaster flask of very valuable ointment with her, and as Jesus reclined at the table, she poured the ointment on His head.

8.verse: The disciples, seeing this scene, were furious. Disciples: This is an absolute waste!

9.verse: The woman could have sold that ointment for lots of money, and then she could have given it to the poor.

10.verse: Jesus knew what the disciples were saying among themselves, so He took them to task. Jesus: Why don’t you leave this woman alone? She has done a good thing.

11.verse: It is good that you are concerned about the poor, but the poor will always be with you—I will not be.

12.verse: In pouring this ointment on My body, she has prepared Me for My burial.

13.verse: I tell you this: the good news of the kingdom of God will be spread all over the world, and wherever the good news travels, people will tell the story of this woman and her good discipleship. And people will remember her.

14.verse: At that, one of the twelve, Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests.

15.verse: Judas Iscariot: What will you give me to turn Him over to you? They offered him 30 pieces of silver.

16.verse: And from that moment, he began to watch for a chance to betray Jesus.

17.verse: Here begins the account of Jesus’ last night before His trial and crucifixion. On the first day of the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the disciples said to Jesus, Disciples: Where would You like us to prepare the Passover meal for You?

18.verse: Jesus: Go into the city, find a certain man, and say to him, “The Teacher says, ‘My time is near, and I am going to celebrate Passover at your house with My disciples.’”

19.verse: They find the man’s house and secure the owner’s permission, and there they will praise God for redeeming His people from bondage in Egypt. So the disciples went off, followed Jesus’ instructions, and got the Passover meal ready.

20.verse: When evening came, Jesus sat down with the twelve.

21.verse: And they ate their dinner. Jesus: I tell you this: one of you here will betray Me.

22.verse: The disciples, of course, were horrified. A Disciple: Not me! Another Disciple: It’s not me, Master, is it?

23.verse: Jesus: It’s the one who shared this dish of food with Me. That is the one who will betray Me.

24.verse: Just as our sacred Scripture has taught, the Son of Man is on His way. But there will be nothing but misery for he who hands Him over. That man will wish he had never been born.

25.verse: At that, Judas, who was indeed planning to betray Him, said, Judas Iscariot: It’s not me, Master, is it? Jesus: I believe you’ve just answered your own question.

26.verse: As they were eating, Jesus took some bread. He offered a blessing over the bread, and then He broke it and gave it to His disciples. Jesus: Take this and eat; it is My body.

27.verse: And then He took the cup of wine, He made a blessing over it, and He passed it around the table. Jesus: Take this and drink, all of you:

28.verse: this is My blood of the new covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins.

29.verse: But I tell you: I will not drink of the fruit of the vine again until I am with you once more, drinking in the kingdom of My Father.

30.verse: The meal concluded. Together, all the men sang a hymn of praise and thanksgiving, and then they took a late evening walk to the Mount of Olives.

31.verse: Jesus: Scripture says, I shall strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will scatter. Just so, each of you will stumble tonight, stumble and fall, on account of Me.

32.verse: Afterward I will be raised up. And I will go before you to Galilee.

33.verse: Peter: Lord, maybe everyone else will trip and fall tonight, but I will not. I’ll be beside You. I won’t falter.

34.verse: Jesus: If only that were true. In fact, this very night, before the cock crows in the morning, you will deny Me three times.

35.verse: Peter: No! I won’t deny You. Even if that means I have to die with You! And each of the disciples echoed Peter.

36.verse: It is indeed a dark, bitter night. The disciples are sad and confused, and maybe a little bit prideful. Peter can not believe that he could ever betray his Lord. At that, Jesus led His disciples to the place called Gethsemane. Jesus: I am going over there to pray. You sit here while I’m at prayer.

37.verse: Then He took Peter and the two sons of Zebedee with Him, and He grew sorrowful and deeply distressed.

38.verse: Jesus: My soul is overwhelmed with grief, to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch with Me.

39.verse: He walked a little farther and finally fell prostrate and prayed. Jesus: Father, this is the last thing I want. If there is any way, please take this bitter cup from Me. Not My will, but Yours be done.

40.verse: When He came back to the disciples, He saw that they were asleep. Peter awoke a little less confident and slightly chagrined. Jesus (to Peter): So you couldn’t keep watch with Me for just one short hour?

41.verse: Now maybe you’re learning: the spirit is willing, but the body is weak. Watch and pray and take care that you are not pulled down during a time of testing.

42.verse: With that, Jesus returned to His secluded spot to pray again. Jesus: Father, if there is no other way for this cup to pass without My drinking it—then not My will, but Yours be done.

43.verse: Again Jesus returned to His disciples and found them asleep. Their eyes were heavy-lidded.

44.verse: So Jesus left them again and returned to prayer, praying the same sentiments with the same words.

45.verse: Again He returned to His disciples. Jesus: Well, you are still sleeping; are you getting a good long rest? Now the time has come; the Son of Man is just about to be given over to the betrayers and the sinners.

46.verse: Get up; we have to be going. Look, here comes the one who’s going to betray Me.

47.verse: There he was, Judas, one of the twelve leading a crowd of people from the chief priests and elders with swords and clubs; the chief priests and the elders were right there, ready to arrest Jesus.

48.verse: And Judas, the one who intended to betray Him, had said to the elders and the chief priests that he would give them a sign. Judas Iscariot: I’ll greet Him with a kiss. And you will know that the one I kiss is the one you should arrest.

49.verse: So at once, he went up to Jesus. Judas Iscariot: Greetings, Teacher (he kisses Him).

50.verse: Jesus: My friend, do what you have come to do. And at that, the company came and seized Him.

51.verse: One of the men with Jesus grabbed his sword and swung toward the high priest’s slave, slicing off his ear.

52.verse: Jesus: Put your sword back. People who live by the sword die by the sword.

53.verse: Surely you realize that if I called on My Father, He would send 12 legions of messengers to rescue Me.

54.verse: But if I were to do that, I would be thwarting the scriptural story, wouldn’t I? And we must allow the story of God’s kingdom to unfold.

55.verse: (to the crowds) Why did you bring these weapons, these clubs and bats? Did you think I would fight you? That I would try to dodge and escape like a common criminal? You could have arrested Me any day when I was teaching in the temple, but you didn’t.

56.verse: This scene has come together just so, so that the prophecies in the sacred Scripture could be fulfilled. And at that, all the disciples ran away and abandoned Him.

57.verse: The crowd that had arrested Jesus took Him to Caiaphas, the high priest. The scribes and elders had gathered at Caiaphas’s house and were waiting for Jesus to be delivered.

58.verse: Peter followed Jesus (though at some distance so as not to be seen). He slipped into Caiaphas’s house and attached himself to a group of servants. And he sat watching, waiting to see how things would unfold.

59.verse: The high priest and his council of advisors first produced false evidence against Jesus—false evidence meant to justify some charge and Jesus’ execution.

60.verse: But even though many men were willing to lie, the council couldn’t come up with the evidence it wanted. Finally, two men stood up.

61.verse: Two Men: Look, He said, “I can destroy God’s temple and rebuild it in three days.” What more evidence do you need?

62.verse: Then Caiaphas the high priest stood up and addressed Jesus. Caiaphas: Aren’t You going to respond to these charges? What exactly are these two men accusing You of?

63.verse: Jesus remained silent. Caiaphas (to Jesus): Under a sacred oath before the living God, tell us plainly: are You the Anointed One, the Son of God?

64.verse: Jesus: So you seem to be saying. I will say this: beginning now, you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of God’s power and glory and coming on heavenly clouds.

65.verse: The high priest tore his robes and screeched. Caiaphas: Blasphemy! We don’t need any more witnesses—we’ve all just witnessed this most grievous blasphemy, right here and now.

66.verse: So, gentlemen, what’s your verdict? Gentlemen: He deserves to die.

67.verse: Then they spat in His face and hit Him. Some of them smacked Him, slapped Him across the cheeks,

68.verse: and jeered. Some of the Men: Well, Anointed One, prophesy for us, if You can—who hit You? And who is about to hit You next?

69.verse: As all this was going on in Caiaphas’s chamber, Peter was sitting in the courtyard with some servants. One of the servant girls came up to him. Servant Girl: You were with Jesus the Galilean, weren’t you?

70.verse: And just as Jesus had predicted, Peter denied it before everyone. Peter: Not me! I don’t know what you’re talking about.

71.verse: He went out to stand by the gate. And as he walked past, another servant girl recognized him. Another Servant Girl (speaking to those standing around): That man over there—he was here with Jesus the Nazarene!

72.verse: Again, just as Jesus had predicted, Peter denied it, swearing an oath. Peter: I don’t know Him!

73.verse: Peter then went to chat with a few of the servants. A little while later, some other servants approached him: Other Servants: Look, we know that you must be one of Jesus’ followers. You speak like you are from the same area as His followers. You’ve got that tell-tale Galilean accent.

74.verse: Cursing and swearing, Peter denied Him again. Peter: I do not know Him! As the exclamation left his mouth, a cock crowed.

75.verse: And Peter remembered. He remembered that Jesus had looked at him with something like pity and said, “This very night, before the cock crows in the morning, you will deny Me three times.” And Peter went outside, sat down on the ground, and wept.

1.verse: Eventually the chief priests and the elders looked around and saw that it was morning. They convened a council meeting whose sole purpose was to hand down Jesus’ death sentence.

2.verse: They tied Jesus up, took Him away, and handed Him over to the governor of Judea, a man called Pilate.

3.verse: Judas—the one who had betrayed Him with a kiss for 30 pieces of silver—saw that Jesus had been condemned, and suddenly Judas regretted what he had done. He took the silver back to the chief priests and elders and tried to return it to them.

4.verse: Judas Iscariot: I can’t keep this money! I’ve sinned! I’ve betrayed an innocent man! His blood will be on my hands. The priests and elders want nothing to do with Judas, and they refuse to take his money. Chief Priests and Elders: We’re through with you, friend. The state of your soul is really none of our affair.

5.verse: Judas threw down the money in the temple, went off, and hanged himself.

6.verse: The chief priests looked at the silver coins and picked them up. Chief Priests and Elders: You know, according to the law, we can’t put blood money in the temple treasury.

7.verse: After some deliberation, they took the money and bought a plot of land called Potter’s Field; they would use it to bury foreigners, suicides, and others who were unfit for a full Jewish burial.

8.verse: (To this day, the field is called Blood Field, because it was bought with blood money.)

9.verse: And when the priests bought Potter’s Field, they unwittingly fulfilled a prophecy made long ago by the prophet Jeremiah: “They took 30 pieces of silver, the price set on the head of the man by the children of Israel,

10.verse: and they gave them for the Potter’s Field as the Eternal One instructed.”

11.verse: Jesus was standing before the governor, Pilate. Pilate: Are You the King of the Jews? Jesus: So you say.

12.verse: The chief priests and the elders stood and poured out their accusations: that Jesus was a traitor, a seditious rebel, a crazy, a would-be Savior, and a would-be king. Jesus stood in the stream of accusations, but He did not respond.

13.verse: Pilate: Do You hear these accusations they are making against You?

14.verse: Still Jesus said nothing, which Pilate found rather astounding—no protests, no defense, nothing.

15.verse: Now the governor had a custom. During the great Jewish festival of Passover, he would allow the crowd to pick one of the condemned men, and he, Pilate, would set the man free. Just like that. Gratuitous, gracious freedom.

16.verse: At this time, they had a notorious prisoner named Barabbas.

17.verse: So when the crowd gathered, Pilate offered them a choice: Pilate: Whom do you want me to free? Barabbas or Jesus, whom some call the Anointed One?

18.verse: Pilate could call Him “Jesus of Nazareth” or “Jesus the Carpenter,” but he says, “whom some call the Anointed One.” It is significant that Pilate is in a position where he passes judgment. He determines who will live and who will die, and he is preparing to hold court. Pilate knew the chief priests and elders hated Jesus and had delivered Him up because they envied Him.

19.verse: Then Pilate sat down on his judgment seat, and he received a message from his wife: “Distance yourself utterly from the proceedings against this righteous man. I have had a dream about Him, a dream full of twisted sufferings—He is innocent, I know it, and we should have nothing to do with Him.”

20.verse: But the chief priests and the elders convinced the crowd to demand that Barabbas, not Jesus, whom-some-call-the-Anointed-One, be freed and that Jesus be put to death.

21.verse: Pilate (standing before the crowd): Which of these men would you have me free? Crowd (shouting): Barabbas!

22.verse: Pilate: What would you have me do with this Jesus, whom some call the Anointed One? Crowd (shouting): Crucify Him!

23.verse: Pilate: Why? What crime has this man committed? Crowd (responding with a shout): Crucify Him!

24.verse: It is clear Pilate has laid his own trap. He realizes he has given the crowd a choice, but the crowd doesn’t choose as he expects them to. Pilate saw that unless he wanted a riot on his hands, he now had to bow to their wishes. So he took a pitcher of water, stood before the crowd, and washed his hands. Pilate: You will see to this crucifixion, for this man’s blood will be upon you and not upon me. I wash myself of it.

25.verse: Crowd: Indeed, let His blood be upon us—upon us and our children!

26.verse: So Pilate released Barabbas, and he had Jesus flogged and handed over to be crucified.

27.verse: The governor’s soldiers took Jesus into a great hall, gathered a great crowd,

28.verse: and stripped Jesus of His clothes, draping Him in a bold scarlet cloak, the kind that soldiers sometimes wore.

29.verse: They gathered some thorny vines, wove them into a crown, and perched that crown upon His head. They stuck a reed in His right hand, and then they knelt before Him, this inside-out, upside-down King. They mocked Him with catcalls. Soldiers: Hail, the King of the Jews!

30.verse: They spat on Him and whipped Him on the head with His scepter of reeds,

31.verse: and when they had their fill, they pulled off the bold scarlet cloak, dressed Him in His own simple clothes, and led Him off to be crucified.

32.verse: As they were walking, they found a man called Simon of Cyrene and forced him to carry the cross.

33.verse: Eventually they came to a place called Golgotha, which means “Place of the Skull.”

34.verse: There they gave Him a drink—wine mixed with bitter herbs. He tasted it but refused to drink it.

35.verse: And so they had Him crucified. They divided the clothes off His back by drawing lots,

36.verse: and they sat on the ground and watched Him hang.

37.verse: They placed a sign over His head: “This is Jesus, King of the Jews.”

38.verse: And then they crucified two thieves next to Him, one at His right hand and one at His left hand.

39.verse: Passersby shouted curses and blasphemies at Jesus. They wagged their heads at Him and hissed.

40.verse: Passersby: You’re going to destroy the temple and then rebuild it in three days? Why don’t You start with saving Yourself? Come down from the cross if You can, if You’re God’s Son.

41.verse: Chief Priests, Scribes, and Elders (mocking Him): He saved others, but He can’t save Himself. If He’s really the King of Israel, then let Him climb down from the cross—then we’ll believe Him.

42.verse: Chief Priests, Scribes, and Elders (mocking Him): He saved others, but He can’t save Himself. If He’s really the King of Israel, then let Him climb down from the cross—then we’ll believe Him.

43.verse: He claimed communion with God—well, let God save Him, if He’s God’s beloved Son.

44.verse: Even the thieves hanging to His right and left poured insults upon Him.

45.verse: And then, starting at noon, the entire land became dark. It was dark for three hours.

46.verse: In the middle of the dark afternoon, Jesus cried out in a loud voice. Jesus: Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani—My God, My God, why have You forsaken Me?

48.verse: One bystander grabbed a sponge, steeped it in vinegar, stuck it on a reed, and gave Jesus the vinegar to drink.

49.verse: Others: We’ll see—we’ll see if Elijah is going to come and rescue Him.

50.verse: And then Jesus cried out once more, loudly, and then He breathed His last breath.

51.verse: At that instant, the temple curtain was torn in half, from top to bottom. The earth shook; rocks split in two;

52.verse: tombs burst open, and bodies of many sleeping holy women and men were raised up.

53.verse: After Jesus’ resurrection, they came out of their tombs, went into the holy city of Jerusalem, and showed themselves to people.

54.verse: When the Centurion and soldiers who had been charged with guarding Jesus felt the earthquake and saw the rocks splitting and the tombs opening, they were, of course, terrified. Soldiers: He really was God’s Son.

55.verse: A number of women, who had been devoted to Jesus and followed Him from Galilee, were present, too, watching from a distance.

56.verse: Mary Magdalene was there, and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.

57.verse: At evening time, a rich man from Arimathea arrived. His name was Joseph, and he had become a disciple of Jesus.

58.verse: He went to Pilate and asked to be given Jesus’ body; Pilate assented and ordered his servants to turn Jesus’ body over to Joseph.

59.verse: So Joseph took the body, wrapped Jesus in a clean sheath of white linen,

60.verse: and laid Jesus in his own new tomb, which he had carved from a rock. Then he rolled a great stone in front of the tomb’s opening, and he went away.

61.verse: Mary Magdalene was there, and so was the other Mary. They sat across from the tomb, watching, remembering.

62.verse: The next day, which is the day after the Preparation Day, the chief priests and the Pharisees went together to Pilate.

63.verse: They reminded him that when Jesus was alive He had claimed that He would be raised from the dead after three days.

64.verse: Chief Priests and Pharisees: So please order someone to secure the tomb for at least three days. Otherwise His disciples might sneak in and steal His body away, and then claim that He has been raised from the dead. If that happens, then we would have been better off just leaving Him alive.

65.verse: Pilate: You have a guard. Go and secure the grave.

66.verse: So they went to the tomb, sealed the stone in its mouth, and left the guard to keep watch.

1.verse: After the Sabbath, as the light of the next day, the first day of the week, crept over Palestine, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to the tomb to keep vigil.

2.verse: Earlier there had been an earthquake. A messenger of the Lord had come down from heaven and had gone to the grave. He rolled away the stone and sat down on top of it.

3.verse: He veritably glowed. He was vibrating with light. His clothes were light, white like transfiguration, like fresh snow.

4.verse: The soldiers guarding the tomb were terrified. They froze like stone.

5.verse: The messenger spoke to the women, to Mary Magdalene and the other Mary. Messenger of the Lord: Don’t be afraid. I know you are here keeping watch for Jesus who was crucified.

6.verse: But Jesus is not here. He was raised, just as He said He would be. Come over to the grave, and see for yourself.

7.verse: And then go straight to His disciples, and tell them He’s been raised from the dead and has gone on to Galilee. You’ll find Him there. Listen carefully to what I am telling you.

8.verse: The women were both terrified and thrilled, and they quickly left the tomb and went to find the disciples and give them this outstandingly good news.

9.verse: But while they were on their way, they saw Jesus Himself. Jesus (greeting the women): Rejoice. The women fell down before Him, kissing His feet and worshiping Him.

10.verse: Jesus: Don’t be afraid. Go and tell My brothers to go to Galilee. Tell them I will meet them there.

11.verse: As the women were making their way to the disciples, some of the soldiers who had been standing guard by Jesus’ tomb recovered themselves, went to the city, and told the chief priests everything that had happened—the earthquake just after dawn, the heavenly messenger, and his commission to the Marys.

12.verse: The chief priests gathered together all the elders, an emergency conference of sorts. They needed a plan. They decided the simplest course was bribery: they would pay off the guards

13.verse: and order them to say that the disciples had come in the middle of the night and had stolen Jesus’ corpse while they slept.

14.verse: The chief priests promised the soldiers they would run interference with the governor so that the soldiers wouldn’t be punished for falling asleep when they were supposed to be keeping watch.

15.verse: The guards took the bribe and spread the story around town—and indeed, you can still find people today who will tell you that Jesus did not really rise from the dead, that it was a trick, some sort of sleight of hand.

16.verse: The eleven disciples, having spoken to the Marys, headed to Galilee, to the mountain where they were to meet Jesus.

17.verse: When the disciples saw Jesus there, many of them fell down and worshiped, as Mary and the other Mary had done. But a few hung back. They were not sure (and who can blame them?).

18.verse: Jesus came forward and addressed His beloved disciples. The disciples don’t know what to think or how to act. Nothing like this has ever happened before. Jesus: I am here speaking with all the authority of God, who has commanded Me to give you this commission:

19.verse: Go out and make disciples in all the nations. Ceremonially wash them through baptism in the name of the triune God: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

20.verse: Then disciple them. Form them in the practices and postures that I have taught you, and show them how to follow the commands I have laid down for you. And I will be with you, day after day, to the end of the age.
